Cause: Short title, commencement, and territorial application of the Act.
Explanation: The Act consolidates provisions related to offenses, effective from a date appointed by the Central Government. It applies to any person, including those committing offenses outside India under specific circumstances, such as targeting Indian resources.
Illustration: A, a citizen of India, commits murder outside India. He can be tried for murder in India as if the crime were committed within India.
Effect: The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023, applies to all offenses within India and specific extraterritorial crimes. No other law related to mutiny, desertion, or special laws is affected.

Cause: To provide definitions of key terms used in the Act.
Explanation: Defines terms such as "act," "animal," "counterfeit," "Court," "death," "dishonestly," "document," and others to ensure clarity and uniform interpretation of the law.
Illustration: A cheque is considered a document as it may serve as evidence of a transaction.
Effect: Ensures consistency and avoids ambiguity in interpreting the Act.

Cause: To provide clarity and exceptions to definitions and liabilities.
Explanation: Definitions of offences, penal provisions, and illustrations must be read subject to "General Exceptions," ensure uniformity of terms, encompass acts and omissions, and establish liability for joint actions or shared intent.
Illustration: A child under seven cannot commit offences due to the general exception; joint jailors A and B are both guilty of murder due to their shared intent.
Effect: Ensures comprehensive understanding of offences, consistent terminology, accountability for omissions, and appropriate liability based on intent and action.

Cause: The punishments to which offenders are liable under the provisions of this Sanhita.
Explanation: This section outlines the types of punishments applicable under the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita.
Illustration: The punishments include: Death, Imprisonment for life, Imprisonment (rigorous and simple), Forfeiture of property, Fine, and Community Service.
Effect: Specifies the range of punishments offenders can face under the Act.

Cause: The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute any punishment under this Sanhita to any other punishment in accordance with section 474 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023.
Explanation: This section allows the commutation of a sentence by the appropriate Government, which is defined based on the nature of the offence.
Illustration: The appropriate Government may commute a punishment to any other punishment without the offender’s consent.
Effect: Enables the commutation of a sentence by the appropriate Government, depending on jurisdiction.

Cause: In calculating fractions of terms of punishment, imprisonment for life shall be reckoned as equivalent to imprisonment for twenty years unless otherwise provided.
Explanation: This section clarifies how fractions of terms of punishment are to be calculated, specifically for imprisonment for life.
Illustration: Imprisonment for life is treated as equivalent to twenty years unless otherwise specified.
Effect: Establishes the rule for calculating fractions of life imprisonment terms.

Cause: The appropriate Government may, without the consent of the offender, commute any punishment under this Sanhita to any other punishment in accordance with section 474 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023.
Explanation: This section allows the commutation of a sentence by the appropriate Government, which is defined based on the nature of the offence.
Illustration: The appropriate Government may commute a punishment to any other punishment without the offender’s consent.
Effect: Enables the commutation of a sentence by the appropriate Government, depending on jurisdiction.

Cause: The section outlines the amount of fine, default imprisonment, and terms for defaulting on payment of fines.
Explanation: Defines the amount of fine and liability for default payment, including details on imprisonment terms for non-payment and how fines may be levied.
Illustration: A is sentenced to a fine of one thousand rupees and four months’ imprisonment in default. If seven hundred and fifty rupees are paid before one month of imprisonment, A will be discharged.
Effect: Establishes procedures for fines and imprisonment terms for non-payment, including conditions for termination of imprisonment based on payment.

Cause: The section limits the punishment for multiple offences that constitute a single act or offence, unless explicitly stated otherwise.
Explanation: If an act consists of several parts, any of which is an offence, the offender is not punished for more than one of those offences unless expressly stated.
Illustration: A gives Z fifty strokes with a stick. A is only punished for the whole beating, not for each individual blow. However, if A strikes Y while beating Z, A is liable for two separate offences—one for Z and one for Y.
Effect: Limits multiple punishments for offences that make up a single act, ensuring the offender isn't punished multiple times for related actions unless specified.

Cause: The section outlines how a person should be punished when it is uncertain which of several offences they are guilty of.
Explanation: If the judgment is unclear about which offence the offender committed, the offender will be punished with the lowest punishment for any of the possible offences, provided the same punishment is not specified for all.
Illustration: If it is uncertain whether an offender committed offence A or offence B, and the punishment for offence A is lighter than for offence B, the offender will receive the punishment for offence A.
Effect: Ensures the offender is given the least severe punishment in cases of uncertainty about which offence was committed.

Cause: The section allows for solitary confinement as part of the sentence for certain offences involving rigorous imprisonment.
Explanation: If a person is convicted of an offence punishable by rigorous imprisonment, the Court may order solitary confinement for a portion of the sentence, with limits based on the length of the imprisonment.
Illustration: If the imprisonment is less than six months, solitary confinement may last up to one month. If the imprisonment exceeds six months but not one year, it can last up to two months, and up to three months for terms exceeding one year.
Effect: Provides the Court with the authority to impose solitary confinement as part of the sentence for certain offences, within defined limits.

Cause: The section places limits on the duration of solitary confinement during imprisonment.
Explanation: Solitary confinement cannot exceed fourteen days at a time, and there must be intervals of at least the same length. If imprisonment exceeds three months, solitary confinement is limited to seven days per month, with similar intervals between periods.
Illustration: If an offender is sentenced to six months in prison, solitary confinement cannot exceed fourteen days at once, and there must be intervals of at least fourteen days between each period of solitary confinement.
Effect: Ensures that solitary confinement is used within strict limits to avoid excessive isolation.

Cause: The section provides for enhanced punishment for repeat offenders convicted under specific chapters.
Explanation: If a person is convicted of an offence punishable under Chapters X or XVII with imprisonment of three years or more, and later commits a similar offence, they face enhanced punishment, including life imprisonment or a term of up to ten years.
Illustration: If someone convicted of an offence under Chapters X or XVII of the Sanhita is later convicted again for a similar offence, they will face life imprisonment or a term of up to ten years.
Effect: Establishes stricter penalties for repeat offenders to deter further criminal activity.

Cause: The section exempts a person from liability if they act under a legal obligation or due to a genuine mistake of fact.
Explanation: If a person acts under a mistake of fact, in good faith, believing themselves to be bound by law, they do not commit an offence.
Illustration: A soldier fires on a mob by order of his superior officer, believing it is lawful. A has committed no offence. A court officer arrests Z after mistakenly believing Z is the person they are ordered to arrest.
Effect: Protects individuals from criminal liability if they act in good faith under the belief that they are legally bound to do so.

Cause: The section shields a Judge from liability when acting in their judicial capacity under the belief that their actions are legally authorized.
Explanation: A Judge is not guilty of an offence when performing their judicial duties in good faith, based on their belief that the law grants them such authority.
Illustration: A Judge makes a ruling, believing it to be in line with the law, and is not held liable for the decision even if later found incorrect.
Effect: Protects Judges from criminal responsibility for acts done in the course of their judicial duties, as long as they act in good faith.

Cause: The section exempts from liability any act done in pursuance of a Court’s judgment or order, even if the Court lacked jurisdiction, provided the person acted in good faith.
Explanation: An act done following a Court’s judgment or order is not an offence if the person believed in good faith that the Court had jurisdiction, even if the Court did not have jurisdiction.
Illustration: A person acts based on a Court order, believing the Court had jurisdiction, and the act is not an offence despite the lack of jurisdiction.
Effect: Protects individuals from liability when acting under a Court’s order or judgment, provided they act in good faith.

Cause: This section exempts individuals from liability if they act in accordance with the law or in good faith, believing they are justified by law.
Explanation: If a person, acting in good faith, believes they are justified by law to take certain actions, they are not guilty of an offence.
Illustration: A, in good faith, apprehends Z, believing Z is committing a murder, but Z was acting in self-defence. A has committed no offence.
Effect: Shields individuals from liability when they believe they are legally justified in their actions.

Cause: The section protects individuals from liability if they cause harm accidentally while performing a lawful act with care.
Explanation: If harm occurs unintentionally while performing a lawful act in a lawful manner with proper care, no offence is committed.
Illustration: A accidentally kills someone while working with a hatchet, but there was no negligence. A is not guilty of an offence.
Effect: Exempts individuals from liability for accidents during lawful acts, as long as no criminal intent or negligence is involved.

Cause: This section protects individuals from liability if they cause harm while attempting to prevent greater harm, without criminal intent.
Explanation: If harm is caused without criminal intent while trying to prevent a greater harm, it is not an offence, provided the harm was justified.
Illustration: A changes the course of a vessel to avoid running down a boat with more passengers, even though it risks running down a smaller boat. A is not guilty if the danger was imminent and justified the risk.
Effect: Provides a defence for individuals who cause harm to avoid greater harm in good faith.

Cause: A child under the age of seven is exempt from criminal liability for their actions.
Explanation: A child under seven years old cannot be held guilty of committing an offence.
Illustration: A child under seven accidentally breaks something but cannot be held criminally responsible for the act.
Effect: Protects children under seven from criminal liability.

Cause: Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding
Explanation: A child above seven but under twelve who lacks maturity of understanding
Illustration: A child aged between seven and twelve is not guilty of an offence if they lack sufficient maturity to understand the nature and consequences of their actions.
Effect: A child of 9 who lacks the understanding of the consequences of their actions is not guilty of an offence they committed.

Cause: Act of a person of unsound mind
Explanation: Mental illness preventing the person from understanding the nature or wrongfulness of the act
Illustration: A person with a mental illness that prevents them from understanding the nature of their actions or knowing they are wrong is not guilty of an offence.
Effect: A person with severe mental illness commits an act but is unaware that it is wrong due to their condition.

Cause: Act of a person incapable of judgment by reason of intoxication caused against his will
Explanation: Intoxication without consent or knowledge
Illustration: A person who is intoxicated without their knowledge or consent is not guilty of an offence if they cannot understand the nature of their actions due to the intoxication.
Effect: A person unknowingly consumes a substance that intoxicates them and commits an offence without understanding the consequences.

Cause: Offence requiring a particular intent or knowledge committed by one who is intoxicated
Explanation: Intoxication during the commission of an offence requiring intent or knowledge
Illustration: A person who commits an offence requiring specific knowledge or intent while intoxicated will be treated as if they had the same knowledge or intent as if they were sober, unless the intoxication was involuntary.
Effect: A person commits a theft while intoxicated but is treated as if they had the intent to steal, as if they were sober, unless the intoxication was involuntary.

Cause: Act not intended and not known to be likely to cause death or grievous hurt, done by consent
Explanation: Consent given for acts that do not intend or know to cause death or grievous harm
Illustration: An act not intended to cause death or grievous harm, and not known to likely cause such harm, is not an offence if the person consented to it.
Effect: A and Z agree to fence with each other, and Z gets hurt during the game. A is not guilty as Z consented to the risk of harm.

Cause: Act not intended to cause death, done by consent in good faith for person’s benefit
Explanation: Harm caused without intent to cause death, done for the person’s benefit with consent
Illustration: A surgeon performing a high-risk operation for the benefit of a patient, with consent, and without intending death
Effect: Protects individuals from liability when performing acts in good faith for someone’s benefit, as long as death isn't intended.

Cause: Act done in good faith for benefit of child or person with unsound mind, by or by consent of guardian
Explanation: Harm caused to a child or mentally ill person in good faith for their benefit
Illustration: A parent authorizing a risky surgery on their child to cure a painful disease, not intending death
Effect: Protects actions performed by a guardian for the benefit of a child or mentally ill person, but not for harmful or life-threatening actions.

Cause: Consent known to be given under fear or misconception
Explanation: Consent given under fear or misconception, or by someone incapable of understanding
Illustration: Consent given under fear or misunderstanding is not valid if the person acting knows or should have known
Effect: Protects individuals from liability for actions taken based on invalid consent, such as from fear or misunderstanding.

Cause: Exclusion of acts which are offences independently of harm caused
Explanation: Acts that are offences regardless of harm or consent
Illustration: Certain actions, like causing miscarriage, are offences on their own, even if consent is given
Effect: Clarifies that consent is not valid in cases where the act is inherently illegal, regardless of harm or intent.

Cause: Act done in good faith for benefit of a person without consent
Explanation: Harm caused to a person for their benefit, without their consent, in urgent circumstances
Illustration: A surgeon performing an urgent operation on an unconscious patient to save their life
Effect: Allows actions in good faith to be taken without consent when it is impossible to obtain consent in time, provided the act is not intentionally harmful.

Cause: Communication made in good faith
Explanation: Communication made for the benefit of a person, even if it causes harm
Illustration: A surgeon informs a patient they cannot live, leading to shock and death
Effect: Protects individuals from liability for communications made in good faith for the benefit of the recipient, even if harm results.

Cause: Act compelled by threats
Explanation: Act done under threat of instant death, with no reasonable alternative
Illustration: A person forced by dacoits to open a door for a robbery, under threat of death
Effect: Protects individuals from liability for acts done under extreme duress (death threat), provided they did not put themselves in the situation willingly.

Cause: Act causing slight harm
Explanation: Harm caused is so minor that no reasonable person would complain
Illustration: A minor scratch during a fight
Effect: Protects minor injuries that no reasonable person would consider offensive or worth legal action.

Cause: Things done in private defence
Explanation: Act done while exercising the right to defend oneself or others
Illustration: A person defending themselves from an attacker
Effect: Protects individuals from liability for acts done in self-defense or the defense of others.

Cause: Right of private defence of the body and property
Explanation: Right to defend one’s body or property against certain offenses
Illustration: A person defending their house from a robber or their body from an assault
Effect: Recognizes the right to defend oneself, others, and property against theft, robbery, trespassing, etc., within certain limits.

Cause: Right of private defence against the act of a person with unsound mind, etc.
Explanation: Right to private defence against acts by individuals who are not criminally liable due to mental illness, intoxication, or misconception.
Illustration: Z, under mental illness, attempts to kill A; A has the right of private defence even though Z is not guilty.
Effect: Extends the right of private defence even when the attacker is not criminally liable due to mental illness, intoxication, or misconception.

Cause: Acts against which there is no right of private defence
Explanation: No right of private defence against certain acts by public servants or when there is time to seek help from authorities.
Illustration: A person is attacked by a public servant acting in good faith under the color of his office, and no private defence is allowed.
Effect: No right to private defence against acts that do not cause apprehension of death or grievous hurt by public servants or when authorities can be approached.

Cause: When the right of private defence of the body extends to causing death
Explanation: Right of private defence extends to causing death or any harm to the assailant in certain grave situations (e.g., assault with intent to rape or kidnap).
Illustration: A person is assaulted with the intention of committing rape; the victim can defend themselves and cause death to the assailant.
Effect: Protects individuals from liability for causing death or harm to an assailant in specific dangerous situations.

Cause: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death
Explanation: Right of private defence extends to causing harm (other than death) to the assailant in cases not covered in Section 38.
Illustration: A person is attacked but does not have to kill the assailant; instead, they may cause harm to defend themselves.
Effect: Allows individuals to cause harm (other than death) to an assailant in situations where the threat is serious but not life-threatening.

Cause: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of the body
Explanation: Right of private defence starts when there is a reasonable apprehension of danger and continues as long as the threat persists.
Illustration: A person faces a threat of harm, and the right of private defence starts immediately and lasts as long as the danger continues.
Effect: Protects individuals from liability when defending themselves as long as the threat to their body continues.

Cause: When the right of private defence of property extends to causing death
Explanation: Right to private defence of property extends to causing death or harm if the property is threatened by certain serious crimes like robbery, house-breaking, mischief, or theft under certain circumstances.
Illustration: A person is defending their property from a robbery and causes the death of the assailant.
Effect: Allows causing death or harm to protect property from serious offences like robbery or house-breaking.

Cause: When such right extends to causing any harm other than death
Explanation: Right of private defence of property extends to causing harm other than death for less severe offences such as theft, mischief, or criminal trespass.
Illustration: A person defends their property from theft and harms the thief without causing death.
Effect: Protects property while allowing harm (other than death) to be inflicted for theft or mischief.

Cause: Commencement and continuance of the right of private defence of property
Explanation: Right of private defence of property begins when danger to the property is sensed and continues based on the nature of the crime (e.g., till theft is averted or until help from authorities arrives).
Illustration: A person defends against a robbery, and the right continues as long as the assailant poses a threat.
Effect: Ensures the right to defend property continues during a threat and until the danger subsides or authorities intervene.

Cause: Right of private defence against deadly assault when there is risk of harm to innocent person
Explanation: If the defender risks harming innocent bystanders while defending against a deadly assault, they can still exercise their right of private defence.
Illustration: A person fires on a mob attacking him, even if it risks harming innocent children in the crowd.
Effect: Protects individuals who must risk harm to innocents while defending against a serious threat.

Cause: Abetment of a thing
Explanation: A person abets an act by instigating, conspiring, or aiding it, either before or during the act.
Illustration: B knowingly misrepresents facts to a public officer, leading to the wrongful apprehension of C.
Effect: Holds individuals accountable for instigating, aiding, or conspiring to commit a wrongful act.

Cause: Abettor
Explanation: A person abets an offence by instigating, conspiring, or aiding the commission of an act that would be an offence if committed by a legally capable person.
Illustration: A instigates B to commit murder. B fails to do so, but A is still guilty of abetment.
Effect: Holds the abettor accountable even if the act is not committed or the effect of the offence does not occur.

Cause: Abetment in India of offences outside India
Explanation: A person who abets an offence in India but the act is committed outside India is guilty of abetment.
Illustration: A in India instigates B, a foreigner in country X, to commit murder.
Effect: A is guilty of abetting murder, even though it was committed abroad.

Cause: Abetment outside India for offence in India
Explanation: A person who abets an offence committed in India, even from outside the country, is guilty of abetment.
Illustration: A, in country X, instigates B to commit a murder in India.
Effect: A is guilty of abetting a murder in India, despite being abroad.

Cause: Punishment for abetment when act is committed
Explanation: If the act abetted is committed as a result of the abetment, and there is no specific punishment for abetment, the abettor is punished the same as the person committing the offence.
Illustration: A instigates B to give false evidence. B commits the offence. A is punished as if he had committed the offence himself.
Effect: Punishes the abettor similarly to the person who committed the offence.

Cause: Punishment if the abetted person acts with different intention
Explanation: If the person abetted commits the act with a different intention or knowledge than that of the abettor, the abettor is punished as if the act was done with their intention.
Illustration: A abets B to steal, but B does so with an intent to cause harm. A is punished as if he had intended harm.
Effect: The abettor is punished as though the act was committed with their own intention or knowledge.

Cause: Liability when a different act is done
Explanation: When the act abetted is different from the one done, the abettor is liable for the act done if it was a probable consequence of the abetment and committed under the influence of the instigation, aid, or conspiracy.
Illustration: A instigates a child to put poison into Z’s food, but the child mistakenly puts it into Y’s food. A is liable as if he had instigated the poisoning of Y.
Effect: Abettor is held liable for the actual act done if it is a probable consequence of their abetment.

Cause: Cumulative punishment for multiple offences
Explanation: If the act abetted results in multiple offences, the abettor is liable to punishment for each offence.
Illustration: A instigates B to resist distress by force. B causes grievous hurt during the resistance. A is liable for both offences.
Effect: The abettor faces punishment for each distinct offence caused by the abetment.

Cause: Liability for unintended effects
Explanation: If the act abetted causes a different effect than intended by the abettor, but the abettor knew the effect was likely, he is liable for the unintended effect.
Illustration: A instigates B to cause grievous hurt to Z. Z dies, and A is liable for murder if he knew death was likely.
Effect: Abettor is liable for the unintended effect if they knew it was a probable consequence.

Cause: Abettor’s presence when the offence is committed
Explanation: If the abettor is present when the offence occurs, they are deemed to have committed the act or offence.
Illustration: A, who would normally be liable as an abettor, is present when B commits the offence, and A is treated as having committed the offence.
Effect: Presence of the abettor at the scene makes them liable for the offence committed.

Cause: Abetment of a capital offence
Explanation: If the abettor instigates an offence punishable by death or life imprisonment, but the offence is not committed, they can be punished with up to seven years of imprisonment and a fine. If hurt is caused due to the abetment, the punishment increases.
Illustration: A instigates B to murder Z, but Z is not killed. A is liable to imprisonment up to seven years and a fine, and up to fourteen years if hurt is caused to Z.
Effect: The abettor faces significant punishment if the intended serious crime is not committed or results in harm.

Cause: Abetment of an offence punishable with imprisonment
Explanation: If the abetted offence is not committed, and no specific punishment is prescribed for abetment, the abettor is liable to imprisonment up to one-fourth of the longest term for the offence or a fine, or both. If the abettor is a public servant whose duty is to prevent the offence, the punishment increases to up to half of the longest term.
Illustration: A instigates B to give false evidence. A is liable even if B does not give false evidence.
Effect: Abettors are punished based on the offence's potential punishment, with increased liability for public servants.

Cause: Abetment of an offence by the public or more than ten persons
Explanation: If the abettor incites the public or more than ten persons to commit an offence, they are liable to imprisonment up to seven years and a fine.
Illustration: A affixes a placard inciting more than ten people to attack a sect. A is liable for the abetment of violence.
Effect: Abettors who incite large groups face serious punishment, including imprisonment and fines.

Cause: Concealing a design to commit an offence punishable with death or life imprisonment
Explanation: If the abettor conceals a design to commit an offence punishable with death or life imprisonment, they are liable to imprisonment for up to seven years if the offence is committed, or up to three years and a fine if not.
Illustration: A falsely informs the Magistrate about a dacoity, misdirecting efforts and facilitating the crime. A is punished under this section.
Effect: Concealing a crime design that leads to an offence results in serious penalties.

Cause: Public servant concealing a design to commit an offence they must prevent
Explanation: If a public servant knowingly conceals the design of an offence they are duty-bound to prevent, they are liable to imprisonment, fine, or both. The penalty increases if the offence results in death or life imprisonment.
Illustration: A police officer, knowing of a robbery plan, fails to report it. A is liable for the omission.
Effect: Public servants who neglect their duties to prevent crimes face harsh punishments.

Cause: Concealing a design to commit an offence punishable with imprisonment
Explanation: If the abettor conceals the design of an offence punishable with imprisonment, they are liable to imprisonment for a term up to one-fourth of the longest sentence, or one-eighth if the offence is not committed, with a fine or both.
Illustration: A knowingly conceals a design to commit theft. If the theft occurs, A is punished accordingly.
Effect: Concealment of criminal intentions leads to significant legal consequences, even if the crime is not completed.

Cause: Agreement to commit an illegal act or use illegal means
Explanation: Criminal conspiracy occurs when two or more people agree to commit a crime or use illegal methods to perform a non-illegal act.
Illustration: Two people agree to steal but are caught before the theft happens; they are liable for the conspiracy.
Effect: Punishment is similar to abetting the offence (if the offence is punishable with death, life imprisonment, or >2 years); otherwise, up to 6 months imprisonment, fine, or both.

Cause: Attempt to commit an offence punishable by imprisonment
Explanation: A person tries to commit a crime but doesn't fully complete it. If any act is done towards committing the crime, they are liable.
Illustration: A person attempts to steal jewels but finds none in the box; the attempt still qualifies as a crime.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to half the term of the original offence, or fine, or both.

Cause: Penetration or manipulation without consent
Explanation: Defines rape as sexual penetration or manipulation of any body part or object without the woman's consent or in specific circumstances (e.g., under duress, intoxication).
Illustration: A man forces a woman to engage in sexual acts against her will, or in specific conditions like mental incapacity.
Effect: The act of rape is punishable under Section 376 with varying severity depending on circumstances.

Cause: Rape committed by certain individuals (e.g., police officers, public servants)
Explanation: Specifies that rape by individuals in positions of authority (e.g., police officers, public servants) is punished severely, especially if the victim is in custody.
Illustration: A police officer rapes a woman in their custody; they are severely punished.
Effect: Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 10 years, potentially life imprisonment, plus a fine.

Cause: Rape on a woman under 16
Explanation: Punishment for raping a woman under 16 years is severe, with a minimum 20-year sentence or life imprisonment.
Illustration: A person rapes a woman under 16 years.
Effect: Imprisonment for not less than 20 years, up to life imprisonment, with fine for victim rehabilitation.

Cause: Rape on a woman under 12
Explanation: Rape on a woman under 12 years is treated more severely, potentially resulting in the death penalty.
Illustration: A person rapes a woman under 12 years.
Effect: Imprisonment for life or death, plus a fine for the victim's medical expenses and rehabilitation.

Cause: Inflicting injury causing death or persistent vegetative state during the commission of rape
Explanation: If a rape results in the woman's death or causes her to be in a persistent vegetative state, the offender is severely punished.
Illustration: A man rapes a woman, and during the assault, she dies or is left in a persistent vegetative state.
Effect: Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 20 years, up to life imprisonment, or death.

Cause: Sexual intercourse by a husband with his wife who is living separately without consent
Explanation: A husband who has sexual intercourse with his wife during separation, without her consent, faces legal consequences.
Illustration: A husband forcibly has sex with his wife who is living separately, without her consent.
Effect: Imprisonment for 2-7 years and a fine.

Cause: Abuse of position of authority or fiduciary relationship to induce sexual intercourse
Explanation: A person in authority, such as a public servant or hospital staff, induces sexual intercourse by exploiting their position of power.
Illustration: A superintendent of a women’s institution induces a woman under his care to have sex with him.
Effect: Rigorous imprisonment for 5-10 years and a fine.

Cause: Sexual intercourse by deceit or false promises
Explanation: A person who deceives a woman into having sexual intercourse under false pretenses, such as promises of marriage, is punished.
Illustration: A man promises to marry a woman but deceives her, leading to sexual intercourse.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and a fine.

Cause: Rape by multiple persons acting in common intention
Explanation: When a woman is raped by multiple persons acting together, each person is equally liable for the crime.
Illustration: A woman is raped by a group of men, and each of them is held responsible for the crime.
Effect: Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 20 years, up to life imprisonment, and a fine.

Cause: Gang rape of a woman under 18 years
Explanation: If a woman under 18 is gang-raped, the punishment is life imprisonment or death, with additional penalties.
Illustration: A group of men rapes a girl under 18.
Effect: Life imprisonment for the remainder of the person’s natural life, or death, and a fine.

Cause: Conviction under sections 64, 65, 66, or 67 followed by a subsequent conviction
Explanation: A repeat offender convicted of crimes under sections 64, 65, 66, or 67 faces a severe punishment.
Illustration: A man previously convicted of rape (under sections 64-67) is convicted again for a similar offence.
Effect: Imprisonment for life (remainder of natural life) or death.

Cause: Publishing or printing the identity of the victim of specific crimes
Explanation: It is illegal to disclose the identity of victims involved in certain offences without authorization.
Illustration: A newspaper publishes the identity of a rape victim without permission.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 2 years and fine.

Cause: Publishing matters relating to court proceedings without permission
Explanation: It is an offence to publish any matter related to court proceedings without prior court approval.
Illustration: A journalist publishes details about an ongoing court case regarding sexual assault without court consent.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 2 years and fine.

Cause: Assaulting or using force on a woman intending to outrage her modesty
Explanation: An individual using force to outrage a woman’s modesty is punished under this section.
Illustration: A man grabs a woman’s arm and makes suggestive comments, intending to outraged her modesty.
Effect: Imprisonment for 1-5 years and fine.

Cause: Physical contact, request for sexual favours, or showing pornography
Explanation: A man committing certain acts like physical advances, sexual requests, or showing pornography is guilty of sexual harassment.
Illustration: A man makes unwelcome sexual comments or shows inappropriate material to a woman.
Effect: Rigorous imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both.

Cause: Making sexually coloured remarks
Explanation: A man making inappropriate sexual remarks is guilty of harassment.
Illustration: A man makes lewd comments to a woman at work.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 1 year, or fine, or both.

Cause: Assault or criminal force with the intent to disrobe a woman
Explanation: Any act of assault or force to disrobe a woman or compel her to be naked is punishable.
Illustration: A man forcibly tries to remove a woman’s clothing.
Effect: Imprisonment for 3-7 years and fine.

Cause: Watching or capturing a woman's private act and disseminating it
Explanation: Watching, recording, or distributing private acts of a woman is punishable.
Illustration: A man secretly films a woman in her private space and shares the footage.
Effect: Imprisonment for 1-3 years and fine (first conviction); 3-7 years and fine (subsequent convictions).

Cause: Repeatedly following, contacting, or monitoring a woman
Explanation: A man who repeatedly contacts or follows a woman against her will is guilty of stalking.
Illustration: A man repeatedly sends messages to a woman who has asked him to stop.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 3 years and fine (first conviction); up to 5 years and fine (subsequent convictions).

Cause: Words, gestures, or acts intended to insult a woman's modesty
Explanation: Any act or words intended to insult a woman’s modesty is punishable.
Illustration: A man makes obscene gestures or comments to a woman in public.
Effect: Simple imprisonment for up to 3 years and fine.

Cause: Death due to cruelty or harassment related to dowry demands
Explanation: If a woman dies due to burns or injuries within 7 years of marriage, caused by dowry harassment, it’s considered dowry death.
Illustration: A woman is burned to death after being harassed for dowry.
Effect: Imprisonment for 7 years to life.

Cause: Deceit causing a woman to believe she is lawfully married and cohabit with a man
Explanation: A man deceives a woman into believing they are married, causing her to live with him.
Illustration: A man convinces a woman that they are married when they are not, and she lives with him.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Marrying while a spouse is alive and the marriage is void
Explanation: A person remarries while their spouse is still alive and the marriage is void.
Illustration: A person marries again while their first spouse is still alive.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 7 years and fine.

Cause: Concealing the fact of a prior marriage while remarrying
Explanation: A person marries again, hiding the fact that they have a prior spouse.
Illustration: A person remarries while hiding their previous marriage from the new spouse.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Fraudulent marriage ceremony without lawful intent
Explanation: A person goes through a marriage ceremony knowing they aren't lawfully married.
Illustration: A man knowingly goes through a wedding ceremony without intending to marry lawfully.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 7 years and fine.

Cause: Enticing or taking away a married woman with intent for illicit intercourse
Explanation: A person takes a married woman with the intent for illicit relations.
Illustration: A man takes a married woman with the intent of having an affair with her.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, fine, or both.

Cause: Cruelty by husband or his relatives toward the woman
Explanation: A woman is subjected to cruelty by her husband or his relatives.
Illustration: A husband subjects his wife to cruelty, or his relatives do.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 3 years and fine.

Cause: Definition of "cruelty"
Explanation: Cruelty includes willful conduct likely to drive a woman to suicide or harm, or harassment to meet unlawful demands for property.
Illustration: A woman is forced to face threats or physical abuse that may lead to suicide or grave harm.
Effect: No punishment specified, serves as the definition for cruelty under S. 85.

Cause: Kidnapping or inducing a woman for forced marriage or illicit intercourse
Explanation: A person kidnaps or induces a woman to marry against her will or be forced into illicit acts.
Illustration: A woman is abducted to be married off against her will or forced into an illicit relationship.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Causing a woman to miscarry without good faith for saving her life
Explanation: A person causes a miscarriage, except when done in good faith for saving the woman's life.
Illustration: A person intentionally causes a woman to miscarry without a valid medical reason.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 3 years or fine, or both. If the woman is quick with child, up to 7 years and fine.

Cause: Causing miscarriage without the woman's consent
Explanation: A person causes a miscarriage without the woman’s consent.
Illustration: A man forces a woman to miscarry without her consent.
Effect: Imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Same as S. 88
Explanation: Same as S. 88
Illustration: Same as above.
Effect: Imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Causing death with intent to induce miscarriage
Explanation: A person causes the death of a woman with child by intentionally causing a miscarriage.
Illustration: A person induces a miscarriage that leads to the woman’s death.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Causing death without the woman's consent
Explanation: A person causes a woman's death by miscarriage without her consent.
Illustration: A woman’s death is caused by miscarriage induced without her consent.
Effect: Imprisonment for life or as per the punishment in 90(1).

Cause: Act done to prevent the birth of a child alive or cause its death post-birth
Explanation: A person performs an act with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause it to die after birth.
Illustration: A person performs an action that causes the death of a child either before or after birth, without a valid medical reason.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years, or fine, or both.

Cause: Act causing death of quick unborn child
Explanation: A person performs an act that would be considered culpable homicide and causes the death of an unborn child.
Illustration: A person causes an injury to a pregnant woman that leads to the death of her unborn child, even if the woman survives.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Exposing or abandoning a child under 12 years
Explanation: A parent or caregiver leaves a child under 12 years with the intent to abandon them.
Illustration: A parent leaves a child in a public place with no intention of returning.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 7 years, or fine, or both.

Cause: Concealing the birth of a child by disposing of the body
Explanation: A person secretly disposes of the body of a child to conceal the birth.
Illustration: A mother secretly buries or disposes of the body of her dead newborn child.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, or fine, or both.

Cause: Hiring or engaging a child to commit an offence
Explanation: A person hires or employs a child to commit any criminal act.
Illustration: A person engages a child for illegal activities like prostitution or theft.
Effect: Imprisonment for 3 to 10 years, and fine; if the offence is committed, additional punishment as specified.

Cause: Inducing a child for illicit intercourse
Explanation: A person induces a child under 18 to commit acts leading to illicit intercourse.
Illustration: A person tricks or forces a child to go with someone for prostitution.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Kidnapping a child under 10 to steal property
Explanation: A person kidnaps a child under 10 to steal movable property from them.
Illustration: A person abducts a child with the intent to steal their belongings.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 7 years and fine.

Cause: Selling or disposing of a child for prostitution
Explanation: A person sells a child with the intent to use them for prostitution or illicit intercourse.
Illustration: A person sells a child to a brothel or for sexual exploitation.
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Buying a child for prostitution
Explanation: A person buys a child for the purpose of using them for prostitution or illicit acts.
Illustration: A person purchases a child for the purpose of exploiting them in a brothel.
Effect: Imprisonment for 7 to 14 years and fine.

Cause: Causing death with intention or knowledge
Explanation: A person causes death with the intention or knowledge that the act will likely cause death.
Illustration: A person sets a trap intending to kill someone, and the victim dies.
Effect: Imprisonment for life or as per the severity of the offence.

Cause: Culpable homicide with intent or knowledge of death
Explanation: Actions with intent to kill or inflict injury likely to cause death, or an act that is imminently dangerous and likely to cause death.
Illustration: A person shoots someone intending to kill them.
Effect: The act leads to murder, but exceptions like provocation or self-defense may apply.

Cause: Death of an unintended victim
Explanation: If someone kills another person than the one they intended to kill, it is still culpable homicide.
Illustration: A person aims to kill Person A but accidentally kills Person B.
Effect: The person is charged with culpable homicide, as if they had killed the intended victim.

Cause: Punishment for murder
Explanation: The punishment for murder can be death, life imprisonment, or a fine.
Illustration: A person found guilty of murder is sentenced to death.
Effect: Murder conviction leads to death or life imprisonment, with classification as cognizable, non-bailable.

Cause: Murder by a life convict
Explanation: A life convict who commits murder may face death or life imprisonment for the remainder of their life.
Illustration: A life convict kills a prison guard.
Effect: The convict faces death or life imprisonment for committing murder while serving a life sentence.

Cause: Punishment for lesser culpable homicide
Explanation: Imprisonment for life or 5 to 10 years imprisonment, depending on intent.
Illustration: A person causes death by rash driving but doesn't intend to kill.
Effect: The offender may face a reduced sentence of life imprisonment or up to 10 years.

Cause: Causing death by negligence
Explanation: Death resulting from a negligent act may result in imprisonment and a fine.
Illustration: A person kills someone in a car accident due to negligent driving.
Effect: Punishment can range from up to five years of imprisonment and a fine.

Cause: Abetment of suicide
Explanation: Abetting the suicide of a minor or someone of unsound mind is punishable with death or imprisonment.
Illustration: A person encourages a minor to commit suicide.
Effect: The person who abets the suicide faces death, life imprisonment, or up to ten years imprisonment with a fine.

Cause: Abetment of suicide
Explanation: Any act that encourages or aids suicide, regardless of the person's condition.
Illustration: A person persuades another to end their life.
Effect: The abettor faces up to 10 years' imprisonment and a fine.

Cause: Attempted murder
Explanation: An attempt to commit murder can lead to imprisonment of up to 10 years or life imprisonment if injury occurs.
Illustration: A person stabs another but does not kill them.
Effect: The person faces up to 10 years of imprisonment or life imprisonment, depending on injury.

Cause: Attempted culpable homicide
Explanation: A person attempting culpable homicide without intent to murder may face up to 3 years' imprisonment or a fine.
Illustration: A person strikes another intending to hurt but not kill.
Effect: The punishment could be up to 3 years of imprisonment or a fine, with higher penalties if harm is caused.

Cause: Organised crime
Explanation: Any unlawful activity committed by groups of individuals, such as kidnapping, robbery, vehicle theft, trafficking, and economic offences, with severe consequences.
Illustration: A criminal syndicate running a human trafficking racket.
Effect: The syndicate members face severe penalties, including life imprisonment or death, depending on the crime's severity.

Cause: Petty organised crime
Explanation: Crimes like vehicle theft, trick theft, and pickpocketing committed by organised groups causing public insecurity.
Illustration: A gang involved in ATM thefts or snatching.
Effect: Punishment includes imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine.

Cause: Terrorist act
Explanation: Acts intended to threaten India's unity, integrity, security, or disturb public order using hazardous substances like explosives.
Illustration: A person planning a bombing to disrupt public order.
Effect: The offender faces death or life imprisonment and significant fines.

Cause: Hurt
Explanation: Causing bodily pain, disease, or infirmity to any person.
Illustration: A person is injured in a fight, causing pain and discomfort.
Effect: The offender may face penalties for inflicting hurt.

Cause: Voluntarily causing hurt
Explanation: Causing hurt intentionally or knowingly to any person.
Illustration: A person hits someone with the intent to cause injury.
Effect: The person can be punished with up to one year of imprisonment or a fine up to ₹10,000.

Cause: Grievous hurt
Explanation: Includes severe bodily harm such as emasculation, loss of sight, fractures, or life-threatening injuries.
Illustration: A person suffers from permanent disability after a violent attack.
Effect: The offender may face imprisonment and a fine.

Cause: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt
Explanation: Causing grievous hurt intentionally or knowingly.
Illustration: A person causes severe injury, like permanent disfigurement.
Effect: The offender can face imprisonment for up to seven years.

Cause: Voluntarily causing hurt or grievous hurt by dangerous weapons
Explanation: Causing harm using dangerous weapons like firearms, explosives, or animals.
Illustration: A person uses a gun to threaten and injure another person.
Effect: The punishment includes imprisonment for up to three years or a fine, and for grievous hurt, up to ten years of imprisonment.

Cause: Voluntarily causing hurt or grievous hurt to extort property or force illegal acts
Explanation: Causing harm to extort property or compel someone to do something illegal.
Illustration: A person is beaten to hand over money or perform illegal acts.
Effect: The offender faces imprisonment for up to ten years and a fine.

Cause: Voluntarily causing hurt or grievous hurt to extort confession or compel restoration of property
Explanation: Causing harm to extort confessions or force the return of stolen property.
Illustration: A person is tortured to confess to a crime or return stolen items.
Effect: The punishment is up to seven years of imprisonment and a fine, with more severe penalties for grievous hurt.

Cause: Voluntarily causing hurt or grievous hurt to deter public servant from his duty
Explanation: Causes hurt or grievous hurt to a public servant in the discharge of his duty, or to deter any public servant from discharging their duty
Illustration: A person causing hurt to a police officer while they are arresting someone
Effect: Hurt: Imprisonment up to 5 years, fine, or both; Grievous Hurt: Imprisonment 1-10 years, fine

Cause: Voluntarily causing hurt or grievous hurt on provocation
Explanation: Causing hurt or grievous hurt in response to grave and sudden provocation, without intending to hurt anyone other than the provoker
Illustration: A person strikes another in response to a sudden insult
Effect: Hurt: Imprisonment up to 1 month, fine up to ₹5000, or both; Grievous Hurt: Imprisonment up to 5 years, fine up to ₹10,000, or both

Cause: Causing hurt by means of poison, etc., with intent to commit an offence
Explanation: Administering poison or any harmful substance with the intent to hurt or commit an offence
Illustration: A person poisons someone to steal from them
Effect: Imprisonment up to 10 years, fine

Cause: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid
Explanation: Causing permanent damage, deformity, burns, or grievous hurt using acid
Illustration: A person throws acid at another, causing serious disfigurement
Effect: Imprisonment 10 years to life, fine to cover medical expenses; Attempted acid use: 5-7 years imprisonment, fine

Cause: Act endangering life or personal safety of others
Explanation: Recklessly or negligently endangering life or safety of others
Illustration: A person drives dangerously, risking harm to pedestrians
Effect: Imprisonment up to 3 months, fine up to ₹2500, or both; Hurt: Imprisonment up to 6 months, fine up to ₹5000, or both; Grievous Hurt: Imprisonment up to 3 years, fine up to ₹10,000, or both

Cause: Wrongful restraint
Explanation: Obstructing a person from proceeding in a direction where they have a right to go
Illustration: A person blocks a pedestrian path, preventing someone from passing
Effect: Simple imprisonment up to 1 month, fine up to ₹5000, or both

Cause: Wrongful confinement
Explanation: Preventing a person from proceeding beyond certain limits
Illustration: A person locks another in a room, preventing them from leaving
Effect: Imprisonment up to 1 year, fine up to ₹5000, or both; Confinement for 3 days or more: Imprisonment up to 3 years, fine up to ₹10,000, or both; Confinement for 10 days or more: Imprisonment up to 5 years, fine not less than ₹10,000

Cause: Force
Explanation: Causing motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion to a person or substance
Illustration: A person pushes another, causing them to move
Effect: Causes motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion through bodily power, substances, or animals

Cause: Criminal force
Explanation: Intentionally using force on someone without their consent to commit an offence or cause injury, fear, or annoyance
Illustration: A person pushes another in a fight, intending to cause harm
Effect: Imprisonment or fine, or both, for intentional use of force causing injury, fear, or annoyance without consent

Cause: Assault
Explanation: Making gestures or preparations intending to cause apprehension of criminal force
Illustration: A person shakes their fist at another, causing fear of a punch
Effect: Imprisonment or fine for gestures or preparations intending to cause fear of criminal force

Cause: Assault or criminal force to a person, without grave provocation
Explanation: If someone assaults or uses criminal force to another person, other than in response to grave provocation, they face punishment.
Illustration: A person hits another during an argument not provoked by the other party
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 3 months, fine of up to ₹1,000, or both.

Cause: Assaulting or using criminal force to a public servant in the execution of their duty
Explanation: A person uses force against a police officer trying to prevent them from fulfilling their duties
Illustration: A person pushes a police officer while they are arresting someone
Effect: Imprisonment for up to 2 years, fine, or both.

Cause: Assaulting or using criminal force intending to dishonor a person, without grave provocation
Explanation: A person assaults another intending to embarrass or dishonor them
Illustration: Someone slaps another to humiliate them
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, fine, or both.

Cause: Assaulting or using force while attempting theft on someone's property
Explanation: A person uses force to snatch a purse from someone
Illustration: A thief attempts to grab a handbag from a person in the street
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, fine, or both.

Cause: Assault or criminal force to attempt wrongful confinement
Explanation: A person uses force to stop someone from leaving a place
Illustration: A person locks someone in a room to prevent them from exiting
Effect: Imprisonment up to 1 year, fine up to ₹5,000, or both.

Cause: Assaulting or using criminal force on grave provocation
Explanation: A person assaults another in response to sudden grave provocation
Illustration: A person slaps someone after being insulted
Effect: Simple imprisonment up to 1 month, fine up to ₹1,000, or both.

Cause: Kidnapping a person from India or from lawful guardianship
Explanation: Kidnapping a person or child without consent, either from India or from their lawful guardian
Illustration: A person takes a child from their guardian’s custody without permission
Effect: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine.

Cause: Abduction by force or deceit
Explanation: A person forces or deceives another to go from one place to another
Illustration: A person tricks someone into traveling to a different city
Effect: Varies based on the case.

Cause: Kidnapping or maiming a child to use them for begging
Explanation: A person kidnaps or harms a child to make them beg
Illustration: A person kidnaps a child to use them in the streets for alms
Effect: Imprisonment not less than 10 years, or life imprisonment, with fine.

Cause: Kidnapping or abduction with intent to murder or demand ransom
Explanation: A person abducts another to threaten their life or demand ransom
Illustration: A person kidnaps someone to extort money from their family
Effect: Death penalty or life imprisonment, up to 10 years, with fine.

Cause: Importing minors with intent of illicit activity
Explanation: Punishable with up to 10 years imprisonment and fine for importing minors for forced or seduced illicit intercourse.
Illustration: Importing a girl under 21 or boy under 18 for illicit purposes.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Concealing or detaining a kidnapped person
Explanation: Punished similarly as the original act of kidnapping or abduction.
Illustration: Concealing a person who has been abducted.
Effect: Same punishment as for kidnapping or abduction.

Cause: Recruitment or transportation for exploitation
Explanation: Involves force, threats, coercion, fraud, or deception for exploitation, including sexual slavery or forced labor.
Illustration: Trafficking a person using force or fraud for exploitation.
Effect: Imprisonment from 7 years to life, and fine.

Cause: Engaging a trafficked person for sexual exploitation
Explanation: Imprisonment and fine for engaging trafficked persons (especially minors) for sexual exploitation.
Illustration: Engaging a trafficked minor for sexual exploitation.
Effect: Imprisonment from 3 to 10 years (for adults) and fines.

Cause: Import, export, buy, sell, or deal in slaves
Explanation: Punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine for habitual dealing in slaves.
Illustration: Habitual involvement in trafficking or selling slaves.
Effect: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Compelling labor against the person’s will
Explanation: Punishable with imprisonment up to 1 year or fine for forcing labor.
Illustration: Forcing someone to work against their will.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 1 year or fine, or both.

Cause: Waging or attempting war against India
Explanation: Waging war or attempting it against the government, or abetting such acts, is punishable with death or life imprisonment.
Illustration: Joining a rebellion against the government.
Effect: Death or life imprisonment and fine.

Cause: Conspiring to wage war or force government actions
Explanation: Punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years for conspiring against the government.
Illustration: Conspiring to overawe the government with criminal force.
Effect: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine.

Cause: Preparing for war against India
Explanation: Preparing to wage war by collecting arms, men, or ammunition is punishable with life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment.
Illustration: Collecting arms to prepare for war against India.
Effect: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Concealing war preparations
Explanation: Concealing acts or omissions to facilitate war preparations is punishable with imprisonment up to 10 years and fine.
Illustration: Concealing war preparations to help waging war.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 10 years and fine.

Cause: Assaulting or restraining President or Governor to influence their lawful powers
Explanation: Assault or restrain with criminal force or show of force to compel or prevent lawful action
Illustration: Assaulting a Governor to prevent action on a law
Effect: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine

Cause: Acts that excite secession, rebellion, or subversive activities
Explanation: Inducing or encouraging acts endangering India's sovereignty and integrity, via speech, media, or financial means
Illustration: Promoting separatist movements or rebellion
Effect: Imprisonment for life or up to 7 years, and fine

Cause: Waging war against a peaceful foreign state
Explanation: Engaging in or attempting to engage in war against a foreign state at peace with India
Illustration: Waging war against a peaceful neighboring state
Effect: Imprisonment for life or up to 7 years, and fine

Cause: Attacking foreign state territories at peace with India
Explanation: Making preparations or committing depredation (attack) on foreign peaceful state territories
Illustration: Attacking a peaceful foreign nation’s territory
Effect: Imprisonment up to 7 years, fine, and property forfeiture

Cause: Receiving stolen property from war or depredation
Explanation: Receiving property taken in war or depredation without lawful authority
Illustration: Receiving property taken during war or conflict
Effect: Imprisonment up to 7 years, fine, and property forfeiture

Cause: Public servant letting a state or war prisoner escape
Explanation: A public servant allowing a state or war prisoner to escape
Illustration: Allowing a prisoner of war to escape custody
Effect: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years, and fine

Cause: Negligence by public servant causing prisoner escape
Explanation: A public servant negligently allowing a prisoner to escape
Illustration: Negligently allowing a prisoner of war to escape
Effect: Simple imprisonment up to 3 years and fine

Cause: Aiding a prisoner’s escape or resisting recapture
Explanation: Helping, rescuing, or harboring an escaped prisoner or resisting recapture
Illustration: Helping a prisoner of war escape custody
Effect: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years, and fine

Cause: Abetting mutiny or seducing military personnel from duty
Explanation: Encouraging mutiny or seducing military personnel from their allegiance
Illustration: Encouraging a soldier to rebel against orders
Effect: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years, and fine

Cause: Abetting mutiny that leads to actual mutiny
Explanation: If mutiny occurs due to abetment, the person is punished
Illustration: Encouraging mutiny that leads to rebellion in the military
Effect: Death or life imprisonment, or up to 10 years, and fine

Cause: Abetting assault on a superior officer by military personnel
Explanation: Abetting the assault on a superior officer while executing official duties
Illustration: Encouraging a soldier to assault his commanding officer
Effect: Imprisonment up to 3 years and fine

Cause: Abetting assault that leads to actual assault on superior officer
Explanation: Abetting assault that results in the commission of the assault
Illustration: Encouraging assault on a superior officer that occurs due to abetment
Effect: Imprisonment up to 7 years and fine

Cause: Encouraging desertion by military personnel
Explanation: Abetting a soldier, sailor, or airman in deserting their post
Illustration: Persuading a soldier to desert the military
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

Cause: Harbouring or concealing a deserter from the military
Explanation: Harbouring a soldier, sailor, or airman who has deserted
Illustration: Hiding a soldier who has deserted the army
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

Cause: Concealing a deserter aboard a merchant vessel
Explanation: The master or person in charge of a vessel negligently concealing a deserter
Illustration: Ignoring a soldier hidden aboard a merchant vessel
Effect: Fine of 3,000 rupees

Cause: Abetting insubordination among military personnel
Explanation: Encouraging or supporting acts of insubordination by military personnel
Illustration: Encouraging a soldier to act insubordinately
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

Cause: Military personnel not subject to punishment under this Sanhita
Explanation: Military personnel are not liable for certain offenses under this chapter
Illustration: A soldier, sailor, or airman subject to military law
Effect: No punishment under this Sanhita

Cause: Impersonating military personnel
Explanation: Wearing military garb or carrying tokens resembling those of military personnel
Illustration: A civilian wearing military uniform to impersonate a soldier
Effect: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine of 2,000 rupees, or both

Cause: Defining "candidate" and "electoral right"
Explanation: Explaining the meaning of "candidate" and "electoral right" for election law purposes
Illustration: A person nominated as a candidate or exercising their right to vote
Effect: No direct punishment, provides legal definitions

Cause: Offering or accepting bribes related to electoral rights
Explanation: Offering or receiving gratification to influence voting behavior
Illustration: Offering money to a voter to influence their vote
Effect: Imprisonment and penalty as per specific case circumstances

Cause: Interference with free electoral rights
Explanation: Voluntary interference with the free exercise of any electoral right
Illustration: Threatening a candidate or voter to influence their decision
Effect: Punished with imprisonment up to 1 year, fine, or both

Cause: Impersonating another voter
Explanation: Voting in someone else's name or impersonating a deceased or fictitious person
Illustration: Voting as someone else at an election
Effect: Punished with imprisonment up to 1 year, fine, or both

Cause: Bribery during elections
Explanation: Offering or accepting bribery to influence votes
Illustration: Offering money or gifts to voters
Effect: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both

Cause: Undue influence or impersonation at elections
Explanation: Engaging in undue influence or impersonation during voting
Illustration: Threatening voters or impersonating others
Effect: Imprisonment up to 1 year, fine, or both

Cause: Making false statements about candidates
Explanation: Spreading false statements about a candidate’s personal conduct or character
Illustration: Falsely accusing a candidate of criminal behavior
Effect: Fine

Cause: Unauthorized election expenses
Explanation: Incurring or authorizing expenses without the candidate’s written authority
Illustration: Spending money on a public meeting for a candidate without approval
Effect: Fine up to 10,000 rupees

Cause: Failure to keep accounts for election expenses
Explanation: Not maintaining accounts for election-related expenses as required by law
Illustration: Failing to keep a proper record of election-related expenditures
Effect: Fine up to 5,000 rupees

Cause: Counterfeiting currency or government-issued stamps
Explanation: Counterfeiting coins, government stamps, or currency notes
Illustration: Forging a banknote or government stamp
Effect: Imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine

Cause: Using forged or counterfeit currency or government stamps
Explanation: Using or selling counterfeit or forged currency notes or coins
Illustration: Using a fake coin or banknote in a transaction
Effect: Imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine

Cause: Possession of counterfeit currency or stamps
Explanation: Possessing counterfeit coins, notes, or stamps with the intent to use them as genuine
Illustration: Keeping a counterfeit banknote with the intent to use it
Effect: Imprisonment up to 7 years, fine, or both

Cause: Making, using, or delivering documents resembling currency notes.
Explanation: Whoever creates, uses, or delivers any document resembling or calculated to deceive as a currency-note or bank-note commits an offense.
Illustration: Example: A person creates a flyer designed to look like a currency note for promotional purposes, misleading others.
Effect: Punishment: Fine up to ₹300.

Cause: Failure to disclose the maker's details for such documents.
Explanation: If a person refuses to disclose, without lawful excuse, the name and address of the person who printed or made the deceptive document, they commit an offense.
Illustration: Example: A shopkeeper refuses to reveal the source of counterfeit-like promotional materials found in their possession.
Effect: Punishment: Fine up to ₹600.

Cause: Name appearing on documents connected with offenses under sub-section (1).
Explanation: If a name is found on any document connected with the offense under sub-section (1), the associated person can be charged.
Illustration: Example: A person's name appears on a batch of counterfeit promotional documents resembling banknotes, implicating them in the offense.
Effect: Can lead to prosecution under sub-section (1), with the applicable fine of up to ₹300 or additional legal scrutiny.

Cause: Effacing or removing Government-issued stamps with intent to cause loss.
Explanation: Whoever fraudulently removes or effaces writing from a stamped substance, or removes a used stamp to reuse it for a different purpose, commits an offense.
Illustration: Example: A person removes a revenue stamp from a document and attempts to reuse it on another document to avoid paying the Government revenue.
Effect: Punishment: Imprisonment of up to 3 years, fine, or both. Classification: Cognizable, bailable, triable by a Magistrate of the first class.

Cause: Using previously used Government revenue stamps.
Explanation: Whoever fraudulently reuses a Government-issued stamp for revenue purposes, knowing it has already been used, commits an offense.
Illustration: Example: A person removes a used stamp from an old document and reuses it on a new document to avoid paying for a new stamp.
Effect: Punishment: Imprisonment of up to 2 years, fine, or both. Classification: Cognizable, bailable, triable by any Magistrate.

Cause: Erasing or removing marks indicating a Government stamp has been used.
Explanation: Whoever fraudulently erases or removes marks from a Government-issued revenue stamp, or knowingly possesses, sells, or disposes of such a stamp, commits an offense.
Illustration: Example: A person removes the cancellation mark from a revenue stamp and attempts to reuse or sell it for profit, causing loss to the Government.
Effect: Punishment: Imprisonment of up to 3 years, fine, or both. Classification: Cognizable, bailable, triable by a Magistrate of the first class.

Cause: Prohibition of fictitious stamps.
Explanation: Whoever makes, uses, deals in, sells, or possesses fictitious stamps, or possesses tools or materials for making such stamps, commits an offense. A fictitious stamp is one falsely purporting to be issued by the Government for postage purposes.
Illustration: Example: A person creates fake postage stamps resembling official Government-issued stamps and attempts to sell or use them for postal purposes.
Effect: Punishment: Fine up to ₹200. Any fictitious stamps, tools, or materials used to create them may be seized and forfeited. Classification: Cognizable, bailable, triable by any Magistrate.

Cause: Person employed in a mint causing coin to deviate from the lawfully fixed weight or composition.
Explanation: The section punishes any person employed in a mint who intentionally causes a coin to be of different weight or composition than fixed by law, either by action or omission.
Illustration: A mint employee intentionally alters the weight of a coin, which could lead to the production of counterfeit currency.
Effect: Punishment of imprisonment for up to 7 years and fine. The offense is cognizable, non-bailable, and triable by Magistrate of the first class.

Cause: Unlawfully taking coining tools or instruments from the mint.
Explanation: The section punishes anyone who, without lawful authority, takes coining tools or instruments from a mint lawfully established in India.
Illustration: A person unlawfully removes coining tools from a mint with the intent to misuse them for illegal purposes.
Effect: Punishment of imprisonment for up to 7 years and fine. The offense is cognizable, non-bailable, and triable by Magistrate of the first class.

Cause: Definition of "Unlawful Assembly"
Explanation: An assembly of five or more persons becomes unlawful if the common objective is to intimidate, resist the execution of laws, commit crimes, or enforce rights through force or threats.
Illustration: An assembly of five persons blocking a road with the intent to enforce their claim to the road by force.
Effect: The assembly is unlawful if it fits any of the descriptions provided, and those involved are subject to punishment.

Cause: Joining or continuing in an unlawful assembly
Explanation: A person knowingly joins or continues in an unlawful assembly, becoming a member, subject to punishment.
Illustration: A person, aware that an assembly is unlawful, joins the group to resist police intervention.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 6 months, fine, or both.

Cause: Joining or continuing after dispersal order
Explanation: A person knowingly joins or continues in an unlawful assembly after being commanded to disperse.
Illustration: A protest group is ordered to disperse, but individuals knowingly remain in the assembly.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, fine, or both.

Cause: Armed participation in unlawful assembly
Explanation: A person armed with a deadly weapon or anything likely to cause death joins or continues in an unlawful assembly.
Illustration: A person armed with a knife continues participating in a violent protest after being ordered to disperse.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, fine, or both.

Cause: Joining or continuing an assembly causing public disturbance
Explanation: A person knowingly joins an assembly that is likely to disturb the public peace and does not disperse after being commanded.
Illustration: A crowd gathers to protest and is warned by authorities to disperse but remains present.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 6 months, fine, or both.

Cause: Engaging, hiring, or promoting others to join unlawful assembly
Explanation: A person who hires or engages others to join an unlawful assembly is punishable as a member.
Illustration: A leader hires individuals to participate in a violent assembly to disrupt public order.
Effect: Punishment equivalent to membership and participation in the unlawful assembly.

Cause: Harbouring persons for unlawful assembly
Explanation: A person who harbours or assembles individuals aware they are hired for an unlawful assembly is punishable.
Illustration: A house owner allows hired individuals to stay in their home before participating in an unlawful assembly.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 6 months, fine, or both.

Cause: Assisting in unlawful assembly
Explanation: A person engaged in assisting with acts of an unlawful assembly is subject to the same penalties as the assembly itself.
Illustration: A person is hired to help block roads during a protest.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 6 months, fine, or both.

Cause: Armed assistance in unlawful assembly
Explanation: A person hired to assist in an unlawful assembly while armed is punishable with greater severity.
Illustration: A hired person arrives at a protest armed with a weapon to enforce the group’s demands.
Effect: Imprisonment up to 2 years, fine, or both.

Cause: Liability of all members of unlawful assembly for offence committed in pursuit of common object
Explanation: If any offence is committed by a member of an unlawful assembly while pursuing the common object of that assembly, or if the offence was likely to happen due to the common objective, all members of the assembly are guilty of that offence.
Illustration: A group of protesters commits violence during a demonstration, and all members are considered guilty, even if some did not directly engage in the act.
Effect: All members are liable for the same offence, regardless of individual involvement, with consequences based on the offence type.

Cause: Liability of all members of unlawful assembly for rioting
Explanation: If an unlawful assembly or any of its members uses force or violence in pursuit of the assembly's common objective, all members are guilty of the offence of rioting.
Illustration: A group of individuals involved in a protest resort to violence. All participants are guilty of rioting, whether or not they directly used violence.
Effect: Rioting punishable by imprisonment (up to 2 years, or 5 years if armed with deadly weapon), or fine, or both.

Cause: Maliciously giving provocation with intent to cause riot
Explanation: If a person gives illegal provocation knowing it may cause a riot, they are liable. If a riot happens, punishment extends to a year; if not, up to 6 months or fine.
Illustration: A person shouts provocative statements during a tense situation, knowing it will likely lead to a riot.
Effect: If riot occurs: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both. If no riot: Imprisonment up to 6 months, or fine, or both.

Cause: Liability of landowner or occupier during unlawful assembly/riot
Explanation: If a riot or unlawful assembly occurs on land, the owner or occupier, or anyone claiming an interest in the land, must report it to the police and prevent it from happening.
Illustration: Fine up to 1,000 rupees if they fail to notify the police or take lawful actions to prevent/suppress the riot or assembly.

Cause: Riot for the benefit of the landowner/occupier
Explanation: If the riot is for the benefit of the landowner or their agent/manager, and they don't take lawful actions to prevent or suppress it, they will be liable to fine.
Illustration: Fine for failure to prevent or suppress the riot when they have reason to believe it will happen.

Cause: Affray (fighting in a public place)
Explanation: When two or more persons fight in a public place and disturb the public peace, they are committing an affray.
Illustration: Punishable with imprisonment up to 1 month, or a fine up to 1,000 rupees, or both.

Cause: Assaulting or obstructing a public servant during riot control
Explanation: If someone assaults, obstructs, or uses criminal force against a public servant while they are attempting to disperse an unlawful assembly, suppress a riot, or quell an affray.
Illustration: A person A hits a police officer while trying to disperse a riot.
Effect: Punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years, a fine of at least ₹25,000, or both.

Cause: Threatening or attempting to obstruct a public servant
Explanation: If someone threatens, attempts to assault, or obstructs a public servant in the course of their duties in attempting to disperse an unlawful assembly, suppress a riot, or quell an affray.
Illustration: Person B threatens to harm a police officer while they attempt to control a riot.
Effect: Punishable with imprisonment up to 1 year, or a fine, or both.

Cause: Promoting enmity between groups on grounds of religion, race, etc.
